p: The majority of climate-change impacts assessments have tended to be framed in terms of future time horizons, e.g. impacts by the middle or end of the twenty-first century [ 1, 2]. However, with international climate policy now largely focused on limiting warming to specific levels of global mean temperature such as 2°C [ 3] or 1.5°C [ 4], policy-relevant climate impacts assessments increasingly need to be framed in terms of such warming levels.
